primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: God invades human reality to overcome sin and hopelessness through an 'irruption of grace' that the human subject cannot initiate or imagine.

tekstueel_bewijs: God draws near to them both
God will interrupt the normal progression of things by arriving in—indeed, invading—the midst of human events
He puts redemption into our blanket

object.identificatie: Redemption, New Life, and the removal of fear/sin
tekstueel_bewijs: calling into existence the things that do not exist
bringing the gifts of new life

zender.identificatie: The Holy One of Israel / Yahweh
tekstueel_bewijs: the God who terrifies is also the one who loves us for all eternity

ontvanger.identificatie: The 'Exiles' (Gideon, Peter, the crack addict, the hearer)
tekstueel_bewijs: Jesus stoops down to us in our miserable condition
the promises of God break through to the exiles

helper.identificatie: The 'Enabling Word' / The Son of God
tekstueel_bewijs: the fear is instantly removed by the enabling word 'Fear not'
the Son of God taking upon himself the sin of the world
our selfishness, greed, idolatry, cruelty, pettiness, pomposity, vanity, and self-deceit
if your rebelliousness and mine were allowed to play themselves out to the end, we would be lost
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: Sin is described as a terminal condition ('we would be lost') and an ontological state ('deep in sin') that requires a divine invasion to overcome.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The human attempt to 'turn oneself around' or 'kick the habit'.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Human (e.g., the crack addict, the hearer)
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The secondary program is presented as understandable but ultimately insufficient or secondary to the primary program of divine gift-giving.

voorbeelden_god_subject: God draws near to them both
God will interrupt the normal progression of things
voorbeelden_mens_subject: We are trying to turn ourselves around

voorbeelden: Grant that all who are baptized... may keep the covenant
We can understand and even admire the hope... for something better
the awareness of sin comes only to those who are already standing on the firm ground of their salvation
from a sphere of power capable of calling into existence the things that do not exist
has power to make our resistance go up in flames

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon focuses almost entirely on God's 'ability' (Pouvoir) to act where humans are 'unable' (Incompetent).

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: The sermon moves from S2 (Terror) to S1 (Grace), explicitly stating that S2 is the necessary precursor to S1.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: The tension is resolved through the 'disjunctive' act of the Cross, where God takes the judgment (S2) to give the gift (S1).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: Extremely high; the sermon insists that grace is 'terrifying' and God is 'opposed to us' in our sin.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: The sermon is profoundly theocentric. God is the primary actor, and the human role is defined by receiving a gift that is 'unimagined' and 'undeserved'.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: He does not ask if we are working to turn ourselves around... he puts redemption into our blanket.

indicatoren_genade.indicator: God as Subject of active verbs
indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: God will interrupt the normal progression of things by arriving in—indeed, invading—the midst of human events.

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: Gideon and Peter are used not as moral examples to follow, but as actants who experience the same divine interruption as the hearer.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: The sermon already provides a theocentric reading: God saves Gideon/Peter despite their weakness/sin.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief and 'holy dread'; shifting focus from self-improvement to divine gift.
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Monergistic salvation where God provides the competence the human lacks.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The sermon perfectly integrates the OT and NT narratives into a single movement of divine epiphany and rescue.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: paying in his own body the price of sin, idolatry, addiction, greed, pride

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The Spirit/Word provides the 'Pouvoir' (Fear not) that the human cannot generate.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Critical; sin is an 'addiction' and 'rebelliousness' that leads to being 'lost' without intervention.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The narrative structure is robustly theocentric, with God as the Subject of the primary soteriological program.

modale_halans.voorgestelde_balans: Maintain as is; this is a classic Epiphany/Grace structure.

tegenstander_intensivering.huidige_status: The opponent (sin/death) is already treated as a cosmic, insurmountable force.

narratieve_hierarchie_herstel.voorgestelde_structuur: Soteriology (God's gift) clearly precedes and enables Ethics (human response).

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: This sermon is a masterclass in the 'Grammar of Grace.' It avoids the trap of exemplarism and keeps the focus squarely on the divine Subject.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: While a rhetorical analysis might focus on the 'Port Authority' metaphor's emotional impact, Greimasian analysis reveals that the metaphor functions to strip the human subject of agency (the girl is asleep), reinforcing the monergistic structure.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis might focus on the historical context of Second Isaiah; semiotics shows how the 'New Thing' functions actantially as a 'Subject-switch' from human history to divine invasion.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Greimasian analysis exposes that even when the preacher mentions 'trying to turn ourselves around,' it is structurally subordinated to the 'Object' being placed in the 'Receiver's' blanket by an external 'Subject'.

appendices.notities: The sermon follows Fleming Rutledge's 'Grammar of Grace' almost perfectly.
